name: Ability Scores
description:
When creating your character, you will start with 10s for each of your six ability scores (Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma).

When you pick a Race, you will receive boosts (and possibly a penalty) to some of these stats. You will receive additional boosts based on your background and chosen class at character creation, and will earn additional boosts as your character levels up.

Each of these boosts can raise one of your ability scores by 2, or one of your ability scores by 1 if it is already 20 or higher. The maximum you can raise an ability score to naturally is 24.

Each of these scores is used to calculate a stat modifier that is used in many of your skill checks or other rolls.

subsections.name: Strength
subsections.description:
Strength is the measure of your character’s physical prowess, and ability to physically manipulate the world around them. Swimming, Climbing, Grappling, Leaping, Breaking free, and Carrying are all Strength Ability checks.

Your Strength score determines your melee damage bonus.

subsections.name: Dexterity
subsections.description:
Dexterity measures your agility, reflexes, and balance. Dodging a trap, balancing on a high ledge, picking a lock, and remaining hidden are all dexterity checks.

It is one of the primary stats used to calculate your character’s initiative bonus. Additionally, your dexterity modifier gives you a 5 foot bonus to your move speed if your Dexterity is 20 or higher.

subsections.name: Constitution
subsections.description:
Constitution is the measure of your character’s fortitude, toughness, and ability to endure and outlast whatever hazards you may face. Your maximum hit points increases by your constitution modifier each time you level up (retroactively, meaning an increase to your constitution at level 10 increases your total hit points by 10).

Additionally, every time your character gains the benefits of a rest, you regain hit points equal to your level times your constitution modifier.

subsections.name: Intelligence
subsections.description:
Intelligence measures mental acuity, accuracy of recall, and the ability to reason. Attempts to recall information, understand magical happenings, and investigate an area are all Intelligence checks.

Your intelligence determines your number of apprentice proficiencies at 1st level.

After level 1, each time your Intelligence modifier increases by 1, you also gain a skill increase.

subsections.name: Wisdom
subsections.description:
Wisdom reflects how attuned you are to the world around you and represents perceptiveness and intuition. Any attempts to understand your surroundings, read people, or understand a situation are all Wisdom checks.

Wisdom is one of the primary stats used in calculating your character’s initiative modifier, and is the stat used to calculate a character’s perception bonus.

subsections.name: Charisma
subsections.description:
Charisma is the power of your personality, and your force of will. Persuading or intimidating an NPC, putting on a performance, or lying your way out of trouble are all examples of a Charisma check.

Your Charisma modifier is used to determine your character’s luck score.

name: Languages
description:
There are many languages spoken throughout Valerion. Below follows the list of *most* known languages and their primary speakers:

- Common.......Everyone
- Amarrun...Catfolk
- Celestial.....Inhabitants of the Upper Planes
- Draconic....Dragons and their kin
- Dwarvish...Dwarves
- Elven.........Elves
- Giant.........Giants and other Wild Races
- Gnomish.....Gnomes
- Goblin........Goblins and other subterranean creatures
- Halfling......Halflings
- Infernal.......Inhabitants of the Lower Planes
- Iruxi...........Lizardfolk
- Oruk...........Orcs
- Primordial....Elementals of all types

name: Checks
description:
A check is any attempt made by a player to accomplish a task in game. All checks are made by rolling a d20, and adding whatever modifier is relevant to the situation, whether that be your saving throw modifier, skill modifier, attack modifier, or just your standard ability modifiers.

This combined total is compared against the DC (difficulty class) of the task, with a “meet it to beat it” mindset. DC’s may or may not be known to the player, and the DM will inform them as to whether they have succeeded or failed.

For example, a rogue is attempting to pick a lock (with a Hidden DC of 17). The DM calls for a Thievery check, for which the rogue rolls a 12. The rogue has a +5 Thievery skill, and so they Succeed on the skill check!

name: Skill Proficiency Ranks
description:
Each of your skills uses a “proficiency bonus” when determining the results of your roll. This bonus is determined by your proficiency level with the required skill. There are 6 levels of proficiency, ranging from Unskilled to Legendary. The bonuses from each are as follows:

- Unskilled: 0
- Apprentice: 2
- Trained: 4
- Expert: 6
- Master: 8
- Legendary: 10

name: Luck
description: Each character has a luck pool with a number of points in it equal to their level + their charisma modifier (minimum of 1). This pool represents your character's innate ability to draw on the magical forces of the world around them "pushing" on the fabric of reality to bend it to their will.

subsections.name: Spending your Luck
subsections.description: At any time, you may spend a single point of luck to give yourself advantage (even if you have disadvantage) on any attack, ability check, saving throw, or any other roll.

subsections.name: Running out of Luck
subsections.description: Your pool of luck points is never refilled, however it does increase by one each time you level up and each time your charisma modifier increases. When your character is at 0 luck, the DM may opt to force you to roll a single attack, ability check, saving throw, or any other roll with unmitigatable disadvantage. In doing so, you regain 1 point of Luck.

name: Critical Success and Failure
description:
Whenever you roll an ability check, saving throw, attack roll, or any other check, there is always the chance to critically succeed or fail.

A critical success occurs when you roll a natural 20 on the dice, or when your roll + any modifiers exceeds the target DC by ten or more. When attacking an enemy, a critical success results in doubling the number of damage dice rolled.

A critical failure occurs when you roll a natural 1 on the dice, or when your roll + any modifiers fails to meet the target DC by ten or more.

name: Perception
description:
Your perception bonus is your character’s ability to notice details in your surroundings.

Your perception bonus is your Wisdom Modifier + your level.

Sometimes the DM may ask for your passive perception for determining things you notice while traveling or not actively looking. This score is calculated as 10 + your Wisdom Modifier + your level.

name: Advantage and Disadvantage
description: Sometimes, circumstances may call for a bonus or penalty to your roll. These effects may be minor (like half cover providing a +2 bonus to your Defense), or could be greater. For greater effects, your DM might rule that you have advantage or disadvantage on the roll. In the case of advantage, you will roll the d20 twice and keep the higher of the two rolls. In the case of disadvantage you do the same, only keeping the lower of the two rolls.

name: Attack Rolls
description:
When making a melee attack you will roll a d20, and add any “To Hit” modifiers you may have. Usually this is your Strength Modifier + you level (if you are proficient with the weapon), but certain weapons (such as finesse weapons) may allow you to use Dexterity or another Ability Score to make the attack roll.

When making a ranged attack you will roll a d20, and add any “To Hit” modifiers you may have. Usually this is your Dexterity Modifier + your level (if you are proficient with the weapon), but certain weapons may allow you to use Strength or another Ability to make the attack (for example thrown weapons).

When making a spell attack (ranged or melee) you will roll a d20 and add your Spell Attack modifier to the roll. This modifier is calculated using the relevant Ability Score + your level (if you are proficient in spells of that type).

name: Damage Rolls
description:
When you hit an enemy with a melee attack, you may add your Strength modifier to the damage roll of the attack. This remains true for any melee weapon, even if that weapon allowed you to use a different Ability Score to make the attack roll.

When you hit an enemy with a ranged attack with a ‘fired’ weapon (guns, bows, slings, etc…) , you may NOT add any Ability Score modifier to the damage roll. This remains true regardless if the weapon allows you to make the attack roll with an alternate Ability Score.

When you hit an enemy with a ranged attack with a thrown weapon (javelins, darts, throwing knives or axes, etc...) , you may add your Strength modifier to the damage roll of the attack. This remains true regardless if the weapon allows you to make the attack roll with an alternate Ability Score.

name: Multiple Attack Penalty
description:
Whenever a player takes the Attack action as one of their actions on their turn, they may make a single Melee, Ranged, or Thrown attack. 

If they choose to take this action a second or third time on their turn, that attack roll is made with disadvantage. Some feats, spells, or other abilities might mitigate this disadvantage, negate it entirely, or even replace it with advantage.

Certain characters might take the Multi-attack Ability Feature, which allows them to make multiple attacks in quick succession without facing the multi-attack penalty . Unless otherwise specified, additional attacks you make in the round after completing  a multi-attack ability count each previous attack made when determining your multi-attack penalty.

name: Range Increments
description:
Each ranged weapon has a pair of ranges associated with it that determine its effectiveness.

The first number in a weapons range increment is its effective range: any attacks made up to this distance are made normally.

The second number in a weapon’s range increment is its maximum range: any attacks made at a distance between the effective range and its maximum range are made with disadvantage.

It is impossible to make a successful attack against an enemy at a distance greater than a weapon’s maximum range.

name: Damage
description: Each attack or damaging effect has an Type associated with it. This damage type can be mundane or magical (a bonfire deals regular or mundane fire damage, whereas a meteor storm from a spell deals magical fire damage).

subsections.name: Physical Damage Types
subsections.description:
- Bludgeoning (capable of nonlethal damage)
- Piercing
- Slashing

subsections.name: Elemental Damage Types
subsections.description:
- Acid
- Arcane
- Cold (capable of nonlethal damage)
- Dark
- Fire
- Light
- Lightning (capable of nonlethal damage)
- Poison
- Psychic (capable of nonlethal damage)
- Thunder (capable of nonlethal damage)

name: Resistance and Weaknesses
description:
Some creatures or armors are resistant or weak to attacks from certain elements.

When a target has Weakness to an element, all damage it takes of that type is doubled (rounded up).

When a target has Resistance to an element, all damage it takes of that type is halved (rounded down)

name: Defense Rating
description:
Defense Rating is numeric value of how difficult your character is to damage with an attack. In order to damage a character or object, the attacker must make an attack roll that meets or exceeds their target's Defense.

- Defense =  9 + Dexterity Modifier (minimum of 0, up to your armor’s Defense Cap) + Armor’s Defense Bonus (min 0) + your level.

- Touch Defense = 9 + Dexterity Modifier (minimum of 0, up to your armor’s Defense Cap (if you are wearing armor) + your level

- Still Defense = 9 + Armor’s Defense Bonus + Your level

Each armor set has a different bonus it applies to increase your Defense, and has a maximum Dexterity Bonus that can be applied to your Defense calculation while wearing it.

Each armor also has an Armor value, which is a flat reduction to all damage that your character takes.

Certain armors require a specific level of strength in order to wear them and still move properly. If you do not meet the Strength required for a set of armor, you suffer the full movement speed penalty for wearing that armor. If you do meet the Strength requirement for a set of armor, you can reduce its movement penalty by up to 5 feet. The powerful build racial perk further reduces this penalty by 5 feet.

Armor sets marked with an * are noisy, and force you to make all stealth checks with disadvantage while wearing them.

If you lack proficiency with a given type of armor and still choose to wear it, you gain its full benefits, however: you suffer its full movement penalty regardless of your strength score, make all attack rolls with disadvantage, make all saving throws with disadvantage, and any target you force to make a saving throw does so with advantage.

name: Casting a Spell and Concentration
description:
Most spells have a casting time of two actions, though there are some quick spells and cantrips that have a casting time of one action and some exceptionally powerful spells with a casting time of 3 actions. 

Each class with the spellcasting feature has slightly different mechanics, but there are a few general rules that all spell casters must follow.

- If a spell requires concentration, you must take the Sustain a Spell action as the first action on each of your turns in order to maintain concentration on that spell. If you are concentrating on multiple spells: you may order the Sustain a Spell actions however you wish but they must be done before you can take any other actions.

- Whenever you take damage from an attack, you must make a Fortitude saving throw to maintain concentration on your actively held spells. If you are holding concentration on multiple spells: you make separate rolls for each spell. The DC for these checks is equal to half the damage suffered by the attack (rounded up) or 11, whichever is higher.

name: Spell Attacks
description: When making a spell attack you are proficient with: roll a d20 and add your casting modifier + your level to the roll. This attack does not add any modifiers to the damage rolls of the attack. All damage from spell attacks is considered magical, regardless of its damage type.

name: Spell Save DC
description:
Sometimes a spell or other effect you initiate will cause your target to make a saving throw to avoid its effect. The Difficulty Class for this save is determined by the following calculation:

Spell Save DC = 9 + your casting ability modifier + your level (if you are proficient with spells of that type).

name: Arcanite
description:
Whenever a spell is cast there is a magical byproduct created called Arcanite. Arcanite is a highly unstable compound used in the production of all magical items. With the right care, Arcanite can be kept stable for almost a week, but without the proper storage it will fade within 24 hours. The standard unit of measurement for Arcanite is approximately equivalent to the level of spell casting required to create it. So 1c Arcanite is the byproduct of a single first level spell being cast, while 3c  might be from a single 3rd level spell, three 1st level spells, or a 2nd and 1st level spell. 

As Arcanite is impossible to hoard, Arcanite collectors have replaced treasure hunters in many areas.

name: Runes and Gear Upgrades
description:
Every weapon or set of armor can be upgraded by a skilled enough craftsman. Depending on the quality of the weapon or armor, it might have 1, 2, or 3 rune slots.

Runes fall into two major categories, armor, and weapon runes.

Protection runes for armor and striking runes for weapons do not stack.

name: Initiative
description:
It is often best to avoid conflict, however there are times when it may be unavoidable. In cases of combat, Initiative will be rolled to determine the order in which characters will act. The calculation for this roll is:

D20 + your Wisdom Modifier + your Dexterity Modifier + your level

This roll captures your overall awareness (Wisdom) and your alacrity / ability to quickly act on perceived threats (Dexterity).

name: Saving Throws
description:
Throughout your adventuring, you will face many dangers both mundane and magical. These hazards will force you to make a saving throw: a roll to escape or avoid the harmful effect.

There are three types of saving throws, each based on different ability scores. The details and calculations for these saving throws are as follows:

- Fortitude: (Con or Str + Your Level), used to “endure” (Str to physically resist the effect, constitution to endure its aftermath)

- Reflex: (Dex or Wis + Your Level), used to “avoid” (wisdom to discern a threat, dexterity to get out of its way)

- Will: (Int or Cha + Your Level), used to “resist” (intelligence to understand the attack on your mind, charisma to overpower it)

name: Skills and their Uses
description:
- Arcana: understanding Arcane Magic, the other planes, and archaic runes.

- Athletics: physical prowess and capabilities

- Crafting: turn raw materials into usable items

- Deception: lie convincingly and without repercussions

- Insight: read the truth in a situation or in another person

- Intimidation: convince someone to see things your way … or else

- Investigation: detailed inspection to reveal hidden workings, meaning, or other details

- Lore / History: recall knowledge about a particular topic

- Medicine: practical and theoretical applications of anatomy and herbology

- Nature: interacting with nature in any way, whether that be with plants, animals, or the elements both natural and magical

- Performance: you put on one hell of a show

- Persuasion: convince people to see your side, without cracking skulls

- Religion: knowledge of all entities divine and unholy, the upper and lower planes, and cultural religious history

- Society: understand local customs, familiar with culture locally and nationally, ability to blend in by societal standards

- Stealth: remain hidden in a number of surroundings

- Survival: subsist and thrive in hostile environments

- Thievery: lockpick locks, palm objects, pick pockets, and keister valuables

name: Skill Increases
description:
Each of the skills above has its own unique proficiency bonus that is progressed independently by using “skill increases”. 

At 1st level, your character gains a number of skill increases equal to 2 + their Intelligence modifier (even if your modifier is negative), and a skill they are automatically at the Trained proficiency level with.

At each level after 1st, your character gains a Skill Increase. This increase is used to raise your proficiency level in a single skill by 1 level. The skill proficiency progression is as follows:

Untrained -> Apprentice -> Trained -> Expert -> Master -> Legendary

Whenever your intelligence modifier increases, you gain an additional skill increase.

name: Flat Checks
description: There are times when a certain check will not qualify to have any of your character’s skill proficiencies or other ability score bonuses added to it. In this case, your DM may call for a “flat check”. A flat check is one where the final result of the roll is the result of the roll of the d20 without adding any additional modifiers.

name: Secret Checks
description:
There are times when knowing the result of your roll might adversely affect the integrity of the scene at play. In such cases as these, the DM will ask you for your bonus in a given situation, and roll the d20 themselves. Regardless of the roll, they will inform you of the result (success / failure, etc). 

For example: you and your party are delving into an ancient ruin, and you declare that you wish to search for traps. You know that you have a +8 bonus to perception. If you rolled the dice yourself, and saw that you rolled a 19 on dice, you would be extremely confident that there were no traps around. In the same way, if you rolled a 2 on the dice, even if the DM informs you that “You don’t find any traps” you are likely to proceed with caution as you the player know that the character’s roll wasn’t particularly effective.

In this scenario, knowing your character’s roll greatly influences your character’s behavior in a way they couldn’t explain in game. Using hidden rolls, you would know that “with a +8 to perception, I am pretty good at finding traps” but would be unaware of what dice roll you got. When the DM tells you “you don’t find any traps” your only option is to take that statement and follow it as your character would.

Another such case is stealth. When your character attempts to hide, they are often unaware of their success in doing so. In cases of extreme failure their lack of stealth may be blatantly obvious, but a successful attempt to hide is often a hidden roll.

name: Contest Checks
description:
At certain points in gameplay, players and their enemies will engage in conflict that might be resolved by contested checks. One such example is a Grapple: where a player attempts to grab an enemy, or Sneaking: where a player tries to remain unnoticed while doing other actions.

These contests are resolved in the following way:

The DM determines who is the Initiator or Instigator in the action, and who is the passive / reactive participant.

The DM determines what the appropriate skills are for each participant to use

The Instigator makes the appropriate skill check, which sets the DC for the passive participant to MEET TO BEAT

The results play out based on the result of the contest.

name: Conditions
description: Throughout your adventures, various spells, traps, or other dangers might impose a series of conditions upon your character that alter their interactions and roles. These conditions are as follows:

subsections.name: Blinded
subsections.description:
A blinded creature can’t see and automatically fails any ability check that requires sight.

Attack rolls against the creature have advantage, the creature makes all melee attacks with disadvantage, and all ranged attacks automatically fail.

subsections.name: Charmed
subsections.description:
A charmed creature can’t Attack the charmer or target the charmer with harmful Abilities or magical Effects.

The charmer has advantage on any ability check to interact socially with the creature.

A charmed creature will likely ignore all but the most pressing of circumstances and treat their charmer as a friend despite evidence to the contrary.

subsections.name: Deafened
subsections.description: A deafened creature can’t hear and automatically fails any ability check that requires hearing.

subsections.name: Frightened / Feared
subsections.description:
A frightened creature has disadvantage on Ability Checks and Attack rolls while the source of its fear is within line of sight.

The creature can’t willingly move closer to the source of its fear.

subsections.name: Incapacitated
subsections.description:
An incapacitated creature can’t take Actions or Reactions.

Attack rolls against the creature target the creature’s Still Defense.

subsections.name: Paralyzed
subsections.description:
A paralyzed creature is Incapacitated and can’t move or speak.

The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity Saving Throws.

Any Attack that hits the creature is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.

subsections.name: Petrified
subsections.description:
A petrified creature is transformed, along with any non-magical objects it is wearing or carrying, into a solid inanimate substance (usually stone). Its weight increases by a factor of ten, and it ceases aging.

The creature is Incapacitated, can’t move or speak, and is unaware of its surroundings.

The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity Saving Throws.

The creature has Resistance to all damage.

The creature is immune to poison and disease, although a poison or disease already in its system is suspended, not neutralized.

subsections.name: Poisoned / Weakened
subsections.description: A poisoned creature has disadvantage on Attack rolls and Ability Checks.

subsections.name: Prone
subsections.description:
A prone creature’s only Movement option is to crawl, unless it stands up and thereby ends the condition.

The creature has disadvantage on Attack rolls (excluding attacks with crossbows or firearms).

The creature has advantage on Attack rolls with crossbows and firearms against targets at a range greater than 20 feet.

All melee attack rolls against the creature have advantage, and all ranged attack rolls against the creature have disadvantage.

subsections.name: Grabbed
subsections.description:
A grabbed creature’s speed becomes 0, and it can’t benefit from any bonus to its speed.

The creature’s attack rolls have disadvantage.

The enemy grabbing this creature has advantage on attack rolls against this creature using unarmed attacks or small single handed weapons.

subsections.name: Restrained / Grappled
subsections.description:
A restrained creature’s speed becomes 0, and it can’t benefit from any bonus to its speed.

All Attack rolls against the creature target the creature’s Still Defense.

The restrained creature is incapable of making ranged attacks or attacks with two handed weapons.

The creature has disadvantage on Reflex Saving Throws.

subsections.name: Stunned
subsections.description: A stunned creature is incapacitated (see the condition), and paralyzed (see the condition), can’t move, and can speak only falteringly.

subsections.name: Unconscious
subsections.description:
An unconscious creature is Incapacitated, can’t move or speak, and is unaware of its surroundings

The creature drops whatever it’s holding and falls prone.

The creature automatically fails Reflex and Fortitude Saving Throws.

Attack rolls against the creature target the creature’s Still Defense.

Any Attack that hits the creature is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.

name: Cover
description:
Walls, trees, creatures, and other obstacles can provide cover during combat, making a target more difficult to harm. A target can benefit from cover only when an attack or other effect originates on the opposite side of the cover.

There are three degrees of cover. If a target is behind multiple sources of cover, only the most protective degree of cover applies; the degrees aren’t added together. For example, if a target is behind a creature that gives half cover and a tree trunk that gives three-quarters cover, the target has three-quarters cover.

subsections.name: Half Cover
subsections.description: A target with half cover has a +2 bonus to Defense and Reflex saving throws. A target has half cover if an obstacle blocks at least half of its body. The obstacle might be a low wall, a large piece of furniture, a narrow tree trunk, or a creature, whether that creature is an enemy or a friend.

subsections.name: Three-Quarters Cover
subsections.description: A target with three-quarters cover has a +5 bonus to Defense and Reflex saving throws. A target has three-quarters cover if about three-quarters of it is covered by an obstacle. The obstacle might be a portcullis, an arrow slit, or a thick tree trunk.

subsections.name: Full Cover
subsections.description: A target with total cover can’t be targeted directly by an attack or a spell, although some spells can reach such a target by including it in an area of effect. A target has total cover if it is completely concealed by an obstacle.

name: Exhaustion
description: Missing a night’s rest, as well as some special abilities and environmental hazards, such as starvation and the long-­term effects of freezing or scorching temperatures, can lead to a special condition called exhaustion. Exhaustion is measured in five levels. An effect can give a creature one or more levels of exhaustion, as specified in the effect’s description.

chart.description: Speed halved, Disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws
Hit point maximum halved, Can only use 2 actions per turn
Speed reduced to 0, Cannot regain hit points

name: Hit Points
description:
Your character’s total hit points are calculated using the following algorithm.

Total Hit Points = {hit points at 1st level} + {hit dice roll from each subsequent level up} + {Constitution modifier * your current level -1}

Your hit points at 1st level = Your racial hit points + your identity hit die maximum + your con modifier.

Your hit points at subsequent levels is a collection of numbers from either rolling your identity’s hit dice at each level up, or by taking your identity’s average hit dice roll.

The Con modifier in this algorithm is retroactive, meaning that you do not have to track when your constitution modifier increases. (increasing your constitution modifier by 1 with result in an increase in Hit Points equal to your level).

name: Rest
description:
A Rest is a period of extended downtime at least 8 hours long, during which a character sleeps or performs light activity: reading, talking, eating, or standing watch for no more than 2 hours. If the rest is interrupted by strenuous activity, the characters must begin the rest again to gain any benefit from it.

At the end of a Rest, a character regains a number of hit points equal to their level multiplied by their constitution modifier, and is cured of a single wound.

A character can’t benefit from more than one Rest in a 24-hour period, and a character must have at least 1 hit point at the start of the rest to gain its benefits.

name: Wounds and Dying
description:
Whenever your hit points are reduced to 0 (or below): you are knocked unconscious and begin to fade from this life. At the beginning of each of your turns while unconscious you must make a series of checks (once per round) to determine whether your condition stabilizes or deteriorates. 

This check is a flat (no modifiers added) roll with a challenge DC of 10 (meet it to beat it). After 3 successful saves, you are stabilized: still unconscious and at 0 hit points, but you stop making death saving throws and are no longer dying. After 3 failed saves your character dies. These successes or failures do not need to be consecutive: keep track of both until you get three of a kind. 

 If you roll a 20 on your death saving throw, you gain 1 hit point and immediately stand up and can take actions this turn. If you roll a 1, it counts as two failed rolls. If you suffer any damage while at 0 hit points, it adds 1 failed saving throw to your tally. If the damage comes from a critical hit, it counts as two instead.

Whenever you are stabilized or healed to 1 hit point from unconscious you gain a wound. The next time you are reduced to 0 hit points, you begin with a number of failed saving throws equal to the number of wounds you have. If you have 3 wounds and are reduced to 0 hit points, you instantly die.

name: Actions
description: Each round of combat gains 3 actions and a reaction at the beginning of each of their turns. Reactions may be spent whenever a relevant trigger occurs, and actions are spent on that player’s turn. Players are ordered by their initiative rolls, which occur at the beginning of each combat encounter.

subsections.name: Basic Actions (Common)
subsections.description:
- Stride: 1 Action - Move up to your Speed. 

- Attack: 1 Action - Attack with a weapon or unarmed attack (unarmed attacks do damage equal to 1 + your Strength ability modifier). 

- Cast a Spell: 1-3 Actions - Cast a spell you have prepared or that you know 

- Step: 1 Action - Move 5 feet without triggering reactions.

subsections.name: Basic Actions (Uncommon)
subsections.description:
- Activate an Item: 1 or more Actions - Call forth the effect of an item by properly activating it. 

- Aid: 1 Action - DC 15 check (in the chosen skill) to give advantage to an ally on their attempted check. 

- Delay - Free action: Select this when your turn begins; permanently lower your initiative to a later point in the round. 

- Dismiss: Free action- End one spell effect or magic item effect that you control. 

- Interact: 1 Action - Grab an object, open a door, draw an item, or do a similar action. 

- Draw / Holster: 1 Action - Draw, holster, or sheathe a single weapon

- Mount: 1 Action - Climb on an allied animal bigger than you to ride it. If the animal is not a trained mount, this requires a successful nature check.

- Ready: 1 Action - Prepare to take a single/free action as a reaction with a given trigger. 

- Release: 1 Action - Release something you’re holding without triggering reactions. 

- Sustain a Spell/Activation: 1 Action - Extend a spell or item effect until the end of your next turn. 

- Take Cover: 1 Action - Gain cover.

subsections.name: Basic Actions (Situational)
subsections.description:
- Avert Gaze: 1 Action - Gain advantage on saves against visual abilities. 

- Crawl: 1 Action - Move 10 feet while prone. 

- Drop Prone: 1 Action - Fall prone. 

- Break Free: 2 Actions - Attempt to get free when grabbed, restrained, or immobilized. Use your unarmed attack modifier, Acrobatics, or Athletics. 

- Grab an Edge: 1 Reaction - Try to catch something to stop a fall. 

- Point Out: 1 Action - Reveal a creature you can see to allies who have not observed it. 

- Seek: 1 Action - Scan an area for signs of creatures/objects using Perception. 

- Stand: 1 Action - You stand up from prone.

name: Skill Actions
description:
*ATEML* Denotes that an action requires at least the listed proficiency to perform that action. A range denotes that the ability may or may not be usable in given circumstances.

*S* Denotes that a check is often a secret check, with the DM rolling using your modifiers.

subsections.name: Acrobatics
subsections.description:
- Balance: 1 Action - Move across a narrow surface or uneven ground. 

 - Tumble Through *T*: 1 Action - Move through the space of one enemy.

subsections.name: Athletics
subsections.description:
- Climb: 1 Action - Move up, down, or across an incline (requires an athletics check). 

 - Force Open: 1 Action - Forcefully open a door, window, or container. 

 - Grapple: 1 Action - Attempt to grapple an opponent (athletics contest). 

 - High Jump: 2 Actions - Stride and then vertically jump 3 feet and horizontally 5 feet. 

 - Long Jump: 2 Actions - Stride and then horizontally jump 10 feet (15 feet if your Speed is 35 feet or more)

 - Shove: 1 Action - Contested Athletics checks or be knocked 5 feet in a direction of your choice (+5 feet if Expert or higher).

 - Swim: 1 Action - Propel yourself through water (requires an athletics check). 

 - Trip: 1 Action - force an enemy to make a Fortitude saving throw DC 9 + Athletics + Str. 

 - Disarm *E*: 1 Action - Knock something out of an opponent’s grasp.

subsections.name: Deception
subsections.description: - Create a Diversion: 1 Action - Draw creatures’ attention elsewhere.

subsections.name: Intimidation
subsections.description: - Demoralize *E*: 1 Action - Shake an enemy’s resolve, giving them disadvantage on their next action (that requires a check) (requires an intimidation check vs your target's Will save).

subsections.name: Medicine
subsections.description: - Administer First Aid *E*: 2 Actions - Perform first aid on a dying/bleeding creature, they heal 1 hit point on a success (DC = 10 + 5 * the number of wounds the target has).

subsections.name: Nature
subsections.description: - Command an Animal *T*: 1 Action - Your animal companion or mount gains two actions to use at your direction.

subsections.name: Stealth
subsections.description:
- Conceal an Object *S*: 1 Action -Hide a small object on your person. 

 - Hide *S*: 1 Action - Use cover or concealment to become hidden. 

 - Sneak *S*: 1 Action - Move to another place while being undetected, you move at half your movement speed during this action.

subsections.name: Thievery
subsections.description:
- Palm an Object: 1 Action - Palm a small, unattended object. 

 - Steal: 1 Action - Take a small object from another creature. 

 - Disable Device *T*: 1 Action - Disarm a trap or another complex device. 

 - Pick a Lock *T*: 1 Action - Open a lock without a key.

name: Movement, Terrain, and Traveling
description: Depending on the situation, your character or parties movement speed can vary greatly.

subsections.name: Movement Speed
subsections.description: Each character's movement speed is based off the physical characteristics of their Race. If your Dexterity score is 20 or higher, your movement speed increases 5 feet beyond that typical of your species.

subsections.name: Difficult Terrain
subsections.description:
Your character's speed, or travel pace listed below assumes relatively simple terrain: roads, open plains, or clear dungeon corridors. But adventurers often face dense forests, deep swamps, rubble-filled ruins, steep mountains, and ice-covered ground—all considered Difficult Terrain.

You move at half speed in difficult terrain— moving 1 foot in Difficult Terrain costs 2 feet of movement—so you can cover only half the normal distance in a minute, an hour, or a day.

subsections.name: Travel Pace
subsections.description: While traveling, a group of adventurers can move at around 3 miles per hour, or 24 miles in a day.

subsections.name: Forced March
subsections.description:
The Travel Pace assumes that characters travel for 8 hours a day. They can push on beyond that limit, at the risk of Exhaustion.

For each additional hour of Travel beyond 8 hours, the characters can cover an additional 3 miles, and each character must make a Fortitude saving throw at the end of the hour.

The DC is 10 + 3 for each hour past 8 hours. On a failed saving throw, a character suffers one level of Exhaustion (see Conditions).

name: Mounts
description:
On your turn, you can use one of your actions to Mount a willing creature. If the creature has not been trained as a mount, or is not willing, the action requires a successful Nature check. 

A mount is considered independent if it has an Intelligence score of 6 or higher. Regardless of your mount's Intelligence, they are granted temporary hit points equal to 3 times your level while they serve as your mount. These temporary hit points expire whenever they are not being ridden.

A mount acts during its rider’s initiative, but has its own set of actions and a single reaction. Non-independent mounts do not use their actions unless commanded to do so by their rider. Independent mounts use their actions at their behest under the control of the DM, often following a set of “general tactics” defined by the player while training with the mount.

While mounted, you can use an action to take the Command an Animal action. When you do so, your mount gains two actions to use at your behest. Most animals know the Leap, Seek, Stride, and Strike basic actions. If your mount is independent, a single Command action is sufficient to provide them orders for all of their actions (regardless of how many they may get each turn).

If an animal knows a special action, such as a horse’s Gallop, you can Command the Animal to perform the activity, but you must spend as many actions on Command an Animal as the activity’s number of actions. You can also spend multiple actions to Command the Animal to perform additional actions on its next turn; for instance, you could spend 2 actions to Command an Animal, granting your companion 3 actions, which they might use to Stride three times or to Stride twice and then Strike.

While mounted, you have advantage on all melee attacks against creatures smaller than your mount, and you have half-cover against all melee attacks that do not have the reach property. All attacks against your mount are made as normal.

subsections.name: Taming a Mount
subsections.description:
When in the wilds, it is possible for a player to encounter wild creature’s suitable to serve as a mount, intelligent or otherwise. In order to be tameable, the mount must possess the necessary biological features to serve as a mount, and must be at least one size larger than the tamer (or grow to be one size larger by maturity).

The tamer must attempt a Nature check with a DC of  15 + Creature’s level, with the result of the roll being determined by the table below:

chart.result: The creature becomes hostile and attacks you with one of the attacks in its stat block. You are thrown from the creature’s back, the attack automatically hits, and you are knocked prone. You can make a DC 15+ the creature’s level Athletics check to remount the creature, and then can attempt to continue the taming process. Your next taming check against this creature has disadvantage.

You attempt to train your mount, but the creature is spooked and attempts to buck you off. Make a DC 13 + creature’s level athletics check or be bucked off the creature. If you succeed, immediately repeat the check to tame the creature again. If you fail, you are knocked prone, take 1d6 bludgeoning damage, and must continue the taming process with the DC being increased by 1
You pacify the creature, and it begins to trust you. It serves as a willing mount for the next 8 hours, at which point you must repeat the check to continue the taming process.

You begin to form a bond with the creature. It serves as a willing mount for the next 24 hours, at which point you must repeat the check to continue the taming process. The DC for further checks is lowered by 1.
Your bond solidifies with the creature, and it becomes your permanent mount and loyal ally.

name: Vehicles
description:
For short spans of time (up to an hour), many animals move much faster than Humanoids. A mounted character can ride at a gallop for about an hour, covering up to 10 miles. If fresh Mounts are available every 8 to 10 miles, characters can cover larger distances at this pace, but this is very rare except in densely populated areas.

Characters in wagons, carriages, or other Land Vehicles travel up to 4 miles an hour, except where conditions don't permit vehicles to travel swiftly. Characters in a waterborne vessel are limited to the speed of the vessel. Depending on the vessel and the size of the crew, ships might be able to travel for up to 24 hours per day.

Certain Special Mounts, such as a Pegasus or Griffon, or Special vehicles, such as a Carpet of Flying, allow you to Travel more swiftly.

name: Falling
description: In the rare situation when your character is clumsy and falls, is pushed, or otherwise leaps from a great height, they suffer bludgeoning damage equal to 3d6 for every 10 feet they fall. This damage ignores any armor or resistances.

name: Sneaking, Observed, Concealed, Undetected, and Invisible
description: Over the course of your adventures, you or one of your enemies might find it profitable to hide, or otherwise obscure themselves from view. The following conditions describe a character's visibility, and the rules for interacting with them in each setting

subsections.name: Observed
subsections.description: Any creature that is not hiding or is in plain sight of another creature is Observed. A creature that is observed can be attacked or interacted with at will. There is no bonus or penalty to interacting with them. A creature can attempt to become Concealed or Undetected by making a Stealth Check to hide from all creatures observing it.

subsections.name: Concealed
subsections.description:
A creature that is obscured from onlookers (such as in a partial hiding place, by a thick fog, or other vision impairing effect) is considered Concealed. While concealed, other creatures know what space you are in, but can’t tell your precise pose or exact location. 

You can still be targeted, but you are tougher to hit or interact with. Any creature that attempts to target you with an attack, spell, or other effect must first make a DC 5 Flat check before attempting their action. If the check fails, their attack, spell, or other effect misses you completely. Area effects are not subject to this Flat check.

subsections.name: Invisible
subsections.description:
When you are Invisible, other creatures cannot see you, tell which space you occupy, or target you, though you can still be affected by abilities that target an area. While you are Invisible, you have advantage on all attacks.

While you are Invisible a creature can guess which square you’re in to try targeting you. It must pick a square and attempt an attack. This works like targeting a hidden creature (but instead requires a DC 11 flat check), but the flat check and attack roll are rolled in secret by the GM, who doesn’t reveal whether the attack missed due to failing the flat check, failing the attack roll, or choosing the wrong square.

subsections.name: Undetected
subsections.description:
While undetected, creatures around you are completely unaware of your presence. You’re considered Invisible as long as you remain undetected. Creatures can Seek to attempt to detect you.

If a creature succeeds at its Perception check against your Stealth DC, you become either invisible or concealed depending on the method you were using for stealth. 

If you become invisible while someone can already see you, you start out Concealed to the observer (instead of undetected) until you successfully Sneak. You can’t become observed while invisible except via special abilities or magic.

name: Vision and Light
description: The presence or absence of light in an Environment creates three categories of illumination: Bright Light, Dim Light, and Darkness.

subsections.name: Bright Light / Daylight
subsections.description: Most creatures see normally. Even gloomy days provide bright light, as do torches, lanterns, fires, and other sources of Illumination within a specific radius.

subsections.name: Dim Light / Shadows
subsections.description: Details are lightly obscured in this light. An area of dim light is usually a boundary between a source of bright light, such as a torch or campfire, and surrounding darkness. The soft light of twilight and dawn also counts as dim light. A particularly brilliant full moon might bathe the land in dim light. Any check or roll that requires detailed perception (such as attacks, saving throws, or skill checks) has mitigatable disadvantage while in dim light.

subsections.name: Darkness
subsections.description: Darkness heavily obscures an area. Characters face darkness outdoors at night (even most moonlit nights), within the confines of an unlit dungeon or a subterranean vault, in an unlit building,  or in an area of magical Darkness. Characters cannot see in darkness without magical assistance, and any check that requires vision automatically fails.

name: Sizes
description:
- Tiny - 4 may occupy a single 5 foot square

- Small - 5 foot Square, but treated as small when calculating carry weight, grappling abilities, or other size related factors

- Medium - 5 foot Square

- Tall - 5 foot Square, but treated as large when calculating carry weight, grappling abilities, or other size related factors

- Large - 10 foot Square

- Huge - 15 foot Square

- Giant - 20 foot Square

- Gargantuan - 25 foot Square
